abstract: Investors are criticizing JPMorgan Chase for not sharing its concerns about funds tied to Bernard L. Madoff.
snippet: Investors are criticizing JPMorgan Chase for not sharing its concerns about funds tied to Bernard L. Madoff.
lead_paragraph: JPMorgan Chase says that its potential losses related to Bernard L. Madoff, the man accused of engineering an immense global Ponzi scheme, are “pretty close to zero.” But what some angry European investors want to know is when the bank cut its exposure to Mr. Madoff  and why.

headline.main: JPMorgan Exited Madoff-Linked Funds Last Fall
headline.print_headline: JPMorgan Exited Funds Linked to Madoff

byline.original: By Claudio Gatti and Diana B. Henriques

abstract: JPMorgan Chase says that its potential losses related to Bernard L. Madoff, the man accused of engineering an immense global Ponzi scheme, are “pretty close to zero.” But what some angry European investors want to know is when the bank cut its exposure to Mr. Madoff — and why, The New York Times’s Diana B. Henriques and Il Sole 24’s Claudio Gatti wrote in a joint report.
lead_paragraph: JPMorgan Chase says that its potential losses related to Bernard L. Madoff, the man accused of engineering an immense global Ponzi scheme, are “pretty close to zero.” But what some angry European investors want to know is when the bank cut its exposure to Mr. Madoff — and why, The New York Times’s Diana B. Henriques and Il Sole 24’s Claudio Gatti wrote in a joint report.

headline.main: JPMorgan Exited Madoff-Linked Funds Last Fall

abstract: JPMorgan Chase‘s Jamie Dimon apparently wants one thing and one thing alone: for regulators and legislators to stop jawboning and come up with a solution to the banking industry’s problem.
lead_paragraph: JPMorgan Chase‘s Jamie Dimon apparently wants one thing and one thing alone: for regulators and legislators to stop jawboning and come up with a solution to the banking industry’s problem.

headline.main: Dimon: A Little Less Talking, a Little More Action, Please

abstract: In an interview from Davos with Mario Bartiromo of CNBC, Jamie Dimon of JPMorgan discussed a hot-button issue — the question of whether the big banks are doing enough to unstick the credit markets by making loans.
snippet: In an interview from Davos with Mario Bartiromo of CNBC, Jamie Dimon of JPMorgan discussed a hot-button issue — the question of whether the big banks are doing enough to unstick the credit markets by making loans.
lead_paragraph: Jamie Dimon is a rare breed in Davos: He is one of the few American banking chiefs to come to the World Economic Forum this year. It is probably no coincidence that his company, JPMorgan Chase, is also in much better shape that its domestic rivals as the financial crisis grinds on.
